title: What happened to Tesla’s full self-driving? - Quora

response.answer_text: They have “recognized” about half the revenue from pre-payments to date in their accounting, claiming they have partially delivered the functionality. The biggest deliveries so far were Smart Summon and Stops at Stop Signs functions. You can view youtubes of both. Few owners use Smart Summon today, after a few accidents it caused and youtubes of it acting erratically. Less stress to just walk to your car, and about as fast. The later feature has proved amusing, stopping at round restaurant signs, including a Burger King sign, which BK leveraged into a web ad, stating that Tesla’s AI was so smart that it wanted one of their burgers. It seems embarrassing that their software mistakes a round white and red sign, a bit off the road, for an octagonal solid red sign with large letters “STOP” (almost everywhere in the world). Soon after (about 1 month ago), Elon Musk tweeted that they began rewriting FSD software “from the stack”, which is the lowest level of any software system, and should have it finished by end of 2020. Even stranger, he tweeted an invite a few months earlier for anyone with software experience (no college degree needed) to drop by his house (~5 houses in LA then) to help complete their FSD code. Sounded like a tiger-team lockup session to slam out code, perhaps paid with free pizza. Not sure that happened since CV-19 became much larger than Elon ever expected in the interim. He had tweeted (similar to Pres. Trump) things like “just the flu”, “will be gone by April”, “doesn’t affect children”, and “hydroxychloroquine shows promise”. He still tweets about “erroneous statistics in testing” and such, which has frustrated his fans in the medical community who disagree with his medical understandings.

Self Driving Technology has made huge Strides and is Quite Advanced. Tesla Automobiles are programmed with the latest Self Driving Technology. According to Elon Musk all Tesla Autos will have Level 5 Full Autonomous mode, “very soon”! The Hinderence to utilizing the 100% Full Autonomous mode’ is the limitations by State and Local Government Laws. In the USA, most States restrict Self Driving to “Driver Assist mode” only, and Full Autonomous mode is Not allowed. Therefore the Program operates at a restricted and limited capacity. Typically, Laws require the Driver to be sitting behind the steering wheel, in the Drivers seat, awake, and able to operate the Brake and accelerator. The current mode which is allowed in nearly every Country and State, is the driver assisted mode! 100% Full Autonomous driving in All Areas and on all roads, is still probably 5–10 years ‘Down the Road’ (Pun Intended). Tesla's Elon Musk: Our fully autonomous cars are now 'very close' | ZDNet Also, Elon Musk claims that Autonomous driving will make cars safer. He also is working a plan to offer Insurance companies incentives regarding Cars with Autonomous driving abilities. Driver assisted Self Driving Technology should, in theory, cut down on accidents because of its built in vehicle Avoidance systems. And Now, for some Humor, by the Kidder himself, Elon Musk (from the above article): In April last year, Musk said Tesla would probably have fully autonomous driving by the end of the year and that he would be "shocked" if it didn't by the end of 2020 at the latest, at which point "having a human intervene will decrease safety". “Decrease Safety”, Elon?? Ok, If you day so! Lol What a Kidder!!

Not much “happened” to Tesla’s FSD. It’s been incrementally rolling out. There are a couple of big changes in progress. One is the “3D” neural network. Tesla FSD relies on cameras, which makes it somewhat difficult to judge distance. They’ve rewritten the neural network so that it can be trained with images that are labeled with distance information, so it can learn depth perception. Supposedly this is done, and Elon Musk has it on his car. Tesla was talking about those in the early access program (Kevin jumps and down and yells “me! me! me!) getting it in 6 weeks. The other big deal is mapping parking lots and all their intricate rules. Current Tesla parking lot software like Autopark and Smart Summon, are somewhat rough at present, although I have successfully used both. I’ve found it particularly informative to look for videos on YouTube featuring Andrej Karpathy, head of Tesla’s AI team, at technical conferences. Karpathy also presented at Tesla’s “Autonomy” day last year.[1] Tesla will hold its annual shareholder meeting on September 22, and you may pick up some news there. Footnotes[1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ucp0TTmvqOE

They are still working on it. It is just a much harder problem to solve than anyone anticipated, and will take more work. But they keep making progress. Every month or two, I get an update that makes it a little bit better. A little closer to full self driving. Since I got my car, it now can drive around parking lots without a driver, and stops at stop lights and stop signs. It also got a lot better at changing lanes on a free way. And the more cars they get on the road, the more data they have to train with, and the faster they can get it done. But they still need to make sure it doesn't get confused with stuff like this.  Or this.  Or this.

There was much enthusiasm for self driving and parts of the system are becoming available on vehicles like lane assist, smart cruise control etc. The reality is that to make a car really self driving is difficult. If you make a car self driving in the US will it ‘know’ the difference in the driving rules in Canada and Mexico? No. The problem gets worse in Europe where roads are considerably narrower and apparently Tesla’s brake with oncoming traffic even though there is plenty of space. It is also important to remember that a significant proportion of the world drives on the left! I think it will come but we are still a long way off. I think that Tesla is quiet about it for two reasons, firstly because it is taking a long time and the second the press likes to dramatise accidents that do happen as ‘failures’ of self driving Tesla’s when Tesla has repeatedly said that the current system is driver assistance not full self driving.

Problem, therefore failure: this statement is non sequitur. Problems in this field are merely a bucket list. Full self-driving will arrive little-by-little with no completion date (it will never be complete). When it is reliably safer than 70% or so —or at least 50%) human drivers, most governments will have no problem allowing it on the streets. And it will just keep getting better and better. Tesla is mis-perceived as being behind other researchers mainly because they release each new feature once it is expected to be safer than human drivers. This confuses analysts compared to lab demonstrations and projections. Tesla is not exactly behind 10 other autonomous driving researchers, because it all depends upon what the study is focused on—or gets stuck on. In many ways, Tesla is ahead of all 10 researchers that are ahead in other ways. No company has everything needed, and it will take a lot of cooperation to do it fast. One thing that most article writers do not seem to get is that the human system can no longer be considered the best contender for safest driver. For every failure they point out in past autonomous driving systems, humans have had and continue to have way more risks…

You’ll see even more of drunk drivers for more safely transport plus more of under-aged children to borrow parent’s Tesla car without permission. Parents have to program lock out security, that will prevented children from borrow parent’s Tesla. And of Tesla will be something like Kit on The Knight Rider from old TV show in the 80’s.

I think Tesla’s full self-driving system has gone the same way so many others have gone. It simply wasn’t as near being one hundred percent infallible as it would need to be to be accepted by the general public. A couple of nasty crashes proved that.

The problem with full self-driving is that it requires a massive amount of real world driving data to be effective. Our roads have a massive amount of real world hazards that the software must be able to deal with. I feel that if we had FSD every vehicle that the road would be much safer on average because humans are the greatest wild card that are impossible to out guess.
Still in the works at Tesla, but it will happen, just couldn’t tell you when. I love the Tesla autopilot system I have in my Model 3, self-driving should be awesome when it get perfected.

Well I think people were more accidents because there was probably a recall and people were calling the police cause they thought they did not have there hand on the wheel . but it was just the self drive thing. I think they will make it better once they bring it back
It keeps getting better. Every few months new features get added to my cars with over the air updates. FYI, it's not full self driving yet. Tesla has never said that it was. But it will be someday.
I would not hold my breath, waiting for it. There are simply far too many variables, to large an experiential data set required before the auto drive will be effective.

Musk has been talking end-of-year, but that’s optimistic. I got the computer upgrade, and it’s much better on a back road I take than it used to be, so there is visible progress. I’d say spring ’21 at the earliest.
